SENT.plain: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) resides as a persistent infection in human leukocyte antigen (HLA) class II+ B lymphocytes and is associated with a number of malignancies

The EBV lytic-phase protein gp42 serves at least two functions: gp42 acts as the coreceptor for viral entry into B cells and hampers T-cell recognition via HLA class II molecules through steric hindrance of T-cell receptor-class II-peptide interactions
Here, we show that gp42 associates with class II molecules at their various stages of maturation, including immature alphabetaIi heterotrimers and mature alphabeta-peptide complexes

When analyzing the biosynthesis and maturation of gp42 in cells stably expressing the viral protein, we found that gp42 occurs in two forms: a full-length type II membrane protein and a truncated soluble form
Soluble gp42 is generated by proteolytic cleavage in the endoplasmic reticulum and is secreted
Soluble gp42 is sufficient to inhibit HLA class II-restricted antigen presentation to T cells
In an almost pure population of Burkitt's lymphoma cells in the EBV lytic cycle, both transmembrane and soluble forms of gp42 are detected
These results imply that soluble gp42 is generated during EBV lytic infection and could contribute to undetected virus production by mediating evasion from T-cell immunity
